required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Atomoxetine Versus Placebo for Symptoms of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) in Children and Adolescents With Autism Spectrum Disorder
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Double-blind Comparison of Atomoxetine Hydrochloride and Placebo for Symptoms of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder in Children and Adolescents With Autism Spectrum Disorder

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether atomoxetine is effective in reducing ADHD (Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder) symptoms in children and adolescents with ASD (Autism Spectrum Disorder).

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: ADHD Rating Scale-IV-Parent Version: Investigator Scored - Total Score
primary_outcome.description: Measures the 18 symptoms contained in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Version IV (DSM-IV) diagnosis of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder. Individual item scores range from 0 (none/never or rarely) to 3 (severe/very often). Total scores range from 0 to 54.

secondary_outcome.measure: Clinical Global Impressions-ADHD-Improvement (CGI-ADHD - I)
secondary_outcome.description: Measures total improvement (or worsening) of a patient's ADHD symptoms from the beginning of treatment (1=very much improved, 7=very much worsened).

secondary_outcome.measure: Conners' Teacher Rating Scale - Revised: Short Form (CTRS-R:S)
secondary_outcome.description: A 28-item rating scale (0 [not at all/never] to 3 [very much true/very often]) completed by the teacher to assess problem behaviors related to ADHD. Subscale total scores range from 0 to 15 for Oppositional and Cognitive Problems, 0 to 21 for Hyperactivity, and 0 to 36 for ADHD Index.

secondary_outcome.measure: ADHD Rating Scale-IV-Parent Version: Investigator Scored Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: Measures the 18 symptoms contained in the DSM-IV diagnosis of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder. Individual item scores range from 0 (none/never or rarely) to 3 (severe/very often). Total scores range from 0 to 54.

secondary_outcome.measure: Sleep Measure Scale
secondary_outcome.description: 10-item parent-based scale assessing sleep problems (6 point Likert scale). Scores: Difficulty falling asleep (1-6); Quality of sleep (3-18); Functional outcome (6-36). Lower scores indicate higher problems with item. Open-ended items: Time to fall asleep (1 [0-15 minutes] to 5 [>1 hour]); Total hours (numbers associated with hours of sleep).

secondary_outcome.measure: Aberrant Behavior Checklist (ABC)
secondary_outcome.description: The ABC is a 58-item informant-based scale comprised of five subscales (Irritability [15 items], Lethargy [16], Stereotypic Behaviors [7], Hyperactivity [16], Inappropriate Speech [4]). Individual item scores range from 0 (no problem) to 3 (severe problem). Subscale scores are total of individual item scores in subscale: Irritability (0-45); Lethargy (0-48); Stereotypic (0-21); Hyperactivity (0-48); Inappropriate Speech (0-12).

secondary_outcome.measure: Children's Social Behavior Questionnaire (CSBQ) Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: CSBQ is filled out by parents and consists of 49 items. Items are rated in an ordinal rather than a discrete fashion in order to establish the extent to which problems are present. The CSBQ consists of six subscales. Individual item scores range from 0=does not apply to 2=applies clearly. Total score ranges from 0 to 98.

secondary_outcome.measure: General Health Questionnaire (GHQ) Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: Parental distress is measured with the GHQ. The raw total score (based on 0-0-1-1 scoring system) can be used as an overall index of psychological distress, ranging from 0 to 12 with higher scores indicating more distress.

secondary_outcome.measure: Nijmeegse Ouderlijke Stress Index (NOSI) Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: The NOSI contains 123 items to be completed by the primary caregiver. Individual item scores range from 1 (completely agree) to 6 (completely disagree). Total scores range from 123 to 738.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Focused Attention Task - Error Rates
secondary_outcome.description: Focused attention assessed distractibility. Child needs to identify a specific target (eg, Cherry); non-target is any other fruit. Child presses "yes" when target occurs in relevant position (eg, one of vertical positions on diamond). Child presses "no" when target is absent, or when target appears on horizontal position (irrelevant target). Error rates are percentage of missing relevant targets and percentage of false alarms in response to (irr)relevant (non)targets based on number of errors/total number of trials X 100.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Focused Attention Task - Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
secondary_outcome.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #10. Reaction times (RT) for hits are mean RTs of correct responses to relevant targets. RTs for correct rejections are mean RTs for correct rejections are mean RTs for correct no responses to irrelevant targets and relevant nontargets.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Focused Attention Task - Standard Deviation of Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
secondary_outcome.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #10. Standard deviations of reaction times (RT) assess intraindividual variability in RT and refer to the same conditions as those for mean reaction times described in Outcome Measure #11.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Memory Search Task - Error Rates
secondary_outcome.description: The memory search task aims at measuring serial search processes to be carried out in working memory. There are 2 blocks (loads) with 40 trials each. Load 1 has 1 target to identify (e.g., an animal). A "yes" is required whenever the target is part of the displayed set of four stimuli (all animals). Load 2 has 2 targets. Whenever 1 of the targets appears in the successively displayed sets of four animals, a "yes" is required. Targets are present in 50% of trials. Error rates are the percentages of errors made in each task condition, based on the number of errors/total number of trials X 100.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Memory Search Task - Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
secondary_outcome.description: Memory search task aims at measuring serial search processes to be carried out in working memory. There are 2 blocks (loads) with 40 trials each. Load 1 has 1 target to remember (one animal). A "yes" is required whenever the target is part of displayed set of 4 animals. Load 2 has 2 animals. A "yes" is required whenever one of the animals appears in successively displayed sets of 4 animals. Targets are present in 50% of the trials. Reaction time (RT) for hits is mean RT of correct "yes" responses to targets. RT correct rejections are mean RTs of correct "no" responses when target was missing.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Memory Search Task - Standard Deviation (SD) of Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
secondary_outcome.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #14. Standard deviations of reaction times (RT) assess intraindividual variability in RT referring to the two conditions creating hits and correct rejections as mentioned in Outcome Measure #14.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Pursuit Motor Control Task - Accuracy
secondary_outcome.description: A complex visuo-motor flexibility task that aims at measuring eye-hand co-ordination and fine motor control. By moving mouse cursor, the child is required to follow as closely as possible a target that randomly moves across the PC-screen. Accuracy is the mean distance between the mouse cursor and the moving target.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Pursuit Motor Control Task - Stability of Movement
secondary_outcome.description: A complex visuo-motor flexibility task that measures eye-hand co-ordination and fine motor control. By moving mouse cursor, the child is required to follow as closely as possible a target that randomly moves across the PC-screen. Stability is within subject variability of mean distance between cursor and target.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Go/No-Go Response Inhibition Task - Error Rates
secondary_outcome.description: Measures inhibition of pre-potent responses. 24 Go signals (open squares) are presented, randomly mixed with 24 No-Go signals (closed squares). Subjects are required to press a key if a Go signal (target) appears on the screen but to withhold a response if they see a No-Go signal. Error rate is the percentage of key presses to No-Go signals/total number of trials X 100.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Flanker Interference Task - Error Rates
secondary_outcome.description: Measures ability to neglect stimuli interfering with predefined stimulus-response coupling. Child presented with displays of 9 colored squares. Child responds to color of central square by pressing left mouse key when blue, and right mouse key when yellow. Part 1 (40 trials), surrounding squares may be same color (compatible) or different (neutral). Part 2 (80 trials), in 50% of trials, surrounding squares have color corresponding to predefined key press for other hand (incompatible). Error rates are percentages of errors in response to compatible and incompatible signals, respectively.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Flanker Interference Task - Reaction Times
secondary_outcome.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #19. Mean reaction times (RTs) are computed for correct responses to compatible and incompatible flankers, respectively.

secondary_outcome.measure: Cytochrome P450 2D6 Genotype
secondary_outcome.description: Genotype characterization was used to determine participants' metabolic status.

arm_group.description: atomoxetine 0.5 mg/kg/day every day (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks
placebo every day (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria (most important):
- ASD (autistic disorder or Asperger's disorder or Pervasive Developmental Disorder - Not Otherwise Specified [PDD NOS])
- Criteria A through D for Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
- At least 1.5 standard deviations above the age norm for their diagnostic subtype using published norms for the ADHD Rating Scale-IV-Parent Version
- Intelligence quotient (IQ) score > 60
Exclusion Criteria (most important):
- weight under 20 kg
- Patients who meet Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders Fourth Edition, Text Revision (DSM-IV-TR) criteria for ASD other than Autistic Disorder, PDD-NOS or Asperger's Disorder;history of Bipolar I or II disorder, schizophrenia, another psychotic disorder, substance abuse;Have a significant medical condition such as heart disease, hypertension, liver or renal failure, pulmonary disease, or seizure disorder identified by history, physical examination, or laboratory tests; Patients who have taken (or are currently taking) anticonvulsants for seizure control.
- patients at serious suicidal risk.
- Contraindication to the use of atomoxetine
- Patients who in the investigator's judgment are likely to need psychotropic medications apart from the drug. Patients who at any time during Study Period II are likely to begin a structured psychotherapy, likely to require hospitalization (i.e. in-patient treatment) or likely to be dismissed from in-patient treatment. Psychotherapy (including hospitalization) initiated at least 2 months prior to study participation is acceptable; however, after study participation has begun, only during Study Period III supportive or educational therapy is permitted.

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Study Period I was a screening and wash-out period. Study Period II (visits 2-6) was an 8-week double-blind period. Patients were randomized at Visit 2. Study Period III (visits 6-11) was a 20-week open-label extension period. Treatment groups in Study Period III refer to treatment group assignment during Double-Blind Period.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

participants_list.participants: One patient who completed Study Period II did not enter Study Period III.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Age
Gender
Region of Enrollment
Race/Ethnicity
Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder Rating Scale-IV-Parent Version- Total Score
measure.description: Measures the 18 symptoms contained in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Version IV (DSM-IV) diagnosis of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder. Individual item scores range from 0 (none/never or rarely) to 3 (severe/very often). Total scores range from 0 to 54.

measure.title: Autism Diagnostic Interview-Revised (ADI-R)
measure.description: ADI-R is a highly structured method of eliciting information from a parent to confirm clinical impression of autism. To meet criteria for autism, child must meet criteria in each of 3 content areas (communication [cutoff score=8 for verbal, 7 for nonverbal], social interaction [cutoff score=10], restricted/repetitive behavior [cutoff score=3]).

measure.title: Body Mass Index
measure.description: Body mass index is an estimate of body fat based on body weight divided by height squared.

measure.title: Clinical Global Impression-Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder-Severity Scale
measure.description: Measures severity of the patient's overall severity of ADHD symptoms (1=normal, not at all ill; 7=among the most extremely ill patients).

measure.title: Height
Score for Performance IQ
measure.description: Performance IQ was assessed with the Wechsler Intelligence Scales (WISC-III). There are 5 performal subtests consisting of nonverbal problems, all of which are timed and some of which allow bonus points for extra fast work. The mean score is 100.

measure.title: Score for Verbal IQ
measure.description: Verbal IQ was assessed with the Wechsler Intelligence Scales (WISC-III). There are 5 verbal subtests consisting of oral questions without time limits except for Arithmetic. The mean score is 100.

measure.title: Score for the Overall Scale Intelligence
measure.description: Overall scale intelligence was assessed with the Wechsler Intelligence Scales (WISC-III). The mean score is 100.

measure.title: Weight

outcome.title: Nijmeegse Ouderlijke Stress Index (NOSI) Total Score
outcome.description: The NOSI contains 123 items to be completed by the primary caregiver. Individual item scores range from 1 (completely agree) to 6 (completely disagree). Total scores range from 123 to 738.
outcome.population: Randomized participants with value at timepoint.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Nijmeegse Ouderlijke Stress Index (NOSI) Total Score
measure.description: The NOSI contains 123 items to be completed by the primary caregiver. Individual item scores range from 1 (completely agree) to 6 (completely disagree). Total scores range from 123 to 738.
measure.population: Randomized participants with value at timepoint.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for treatment differences in Total score at 8 weeks.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Focused Attention Task - Error Rates
outcome.description: Focused attention assessed distractibility. Child needs to identify a specific target (eg, Cherry); non-target is any other fruit. Child presses yes when target occurs in relevant position (eg, one of vertical positions on diamond). Child presses no when target is absent, or when target appears on horizontal position (irrelevant target). Error rates are percentage of missing relevant targets and percentage of false alarms in response to (irr)relevant (non)targets based on number of errors/total number of trials X 100.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Focused Attention Task - Error Rates
measure.description: Focused attention assessed distractibility. Child needs to identify a specific target (eg, Cherry); non-target is any other fruit. Child presses yes when target occurs in relevant position (eg, one of vertical positions on diamond). Child presses no when target is absent, or when target appears on horizontal position (irrelevant target). Error rates are percentage of missing relevant targets and percentage of false alarms in response to (irr)relevant (non)targets based on number of errors/total number of trials X 100.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for treatment differences in Error Rate over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Error Rate irrelevant targets over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Error Rate relevant nontargets over time.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Focused Attention Task - Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
outcome.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #10. Reaction times (RT) for hits are mean RTs of correct responses to relevant targets. RTs for correct rejections are mean RTs for correct rejections are mean RTs for correct no responses to irrelevant targets and relevant nontargets.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Focused Attention Task - Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
measure.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #10. Reaction times (RT) for hits are mean RTs of correct responses to relevant targets. RTs for correct rejections are mean RTs for correct rejections are mean RTs for correct no responses to irrelevant targets and relevant nontargets.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

class.title: Mean Reaction Time Hits Baseline (n=34, n=42)
Mean Reaction Time Hits 8 Week (n=33, n=43)

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for Treatment differences in Reaction time over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Mean Reaction Time correct rejections irrelevant target over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Mean Reaction Time correct rejections relevant nontarget over time.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Focused Attention Task - Standard Deviation of Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
outcome.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #10. Standard deviations of reaction times (RT) assess intraindividual variability in RT and refer to the same conditions as those for mean reaction times described in Outcome Measure #11.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Focused Attention Task - Standard Deviation of Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
measure.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #10. Standard deviations of reaction times (RT) assess intraindividual variability in RT and refer to the same conditions as those for mean reaction times described in Outcome Measure #11.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for Treatment differences in Standard Deviation of Reaction Time over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Standard Deviation correct rejections irrelevant target over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Standard Deviation correct rejections relevant nontarget over time.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Memory Search Task - Error Rates
outcome.description: The memory search task aims at measuring serial search processes to be carried out in working memory. There are 2 blocks (loads) with 40 trials each. Load 1 has 1 target to identify (e.g., an animal). A yes is required whenever the target is part of the displayed set of four stimuli (all animals). Load 2 has 2 targets. Whenever 1 of the targets appears in the successively displayed sets of four animals, a yes is required. Targets are present in 50% of trials. Error rates are the percentages of errors made in each task condition, based on the number of errors/total number of trials X 100.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Memory Search Task - Error Rates
measure.description: The memory search task aims at measuring serial search processes to be carried out in working memory. There are 2 blocks (loads) with 40 trials each. Load 1 has 1 target to identify (e.g., an animal). A yes is required whenever the target is part of the displayed set of four stimuli (all animals). Load 2 has 2 targets. Whenever 1 of the targets appears in the successively displayed sets of four animals, a yes is required. Targets are present in 50% of trials. Error rates are the percentages of errors made in each task condition, based on the number of errors/total number of trials X 100.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for Treatment differences in Error Rate over time.
P-value for Treatment*Error Rate absent over time.
P-value for Treatment*Targets Load 1 over time.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Memory Search Task - Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
outcome.description: Memory search task aims at measuring serial search processes to be carried out in working memory. There are 2 blocks (loads) with 40 trials each. Load 1 has 1 target to remember (one animal). A yes is required whenever the target is part of displayed set of 4 animals. Load 2 has 2 animals. A yes is required whenever one of the animals appears in successively displayed sets of 4 animals. Targets are present in 50% of the trials. Reaction time (RT) for hits is mean RT of correct yes responses to targets. RT correct rejections are mean RTs of correct no responses when target was missing.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Memory Search Task - Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
measure.description: Memory search task aims at measuring serial search processes to be carried out in working memory. There are 2 blocks (loads) with 40 trials each. Load 1 has 1 target to remember (one animal). A yes is required whenever the target is part of displayed set of 4 animals. Load 2 has 2 animals. A yes is required whenever one of the animals appears in successively displayed sets of 4 animals. Targets are present in 50% of the trials. Reaction time (RT) for hits is mean RT of correct yes responses to targets. RT correct rejections are mean RTs of correct no responses when target was missing.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

class.title: Reaction Time Hits Load 1 Baseline (n=33, n=35)
Reaction Time Hits Load 1 8 Week (n=34, n=34)

Reaction Time Hits Load 2 8 Week (n=34, n=34)

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for Treatment differences in Reaction Time over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Mean Reaction Time correct rejections Load 1 over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Mean Reaction Time correct rejections Load 2 over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Mean Reaction Time hits Load 1 over time.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Memory Search Task - Standard Deviation (SD) of Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
outcome.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #14. Standard deviations of reaction times (RT) assess intraindividual variability in RT referring to the two conditions creating hits and correct rejections as mentioned in Outcome Measure #14.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Memory Search Task - Standard Deviation (SD) of Reaction Times for Hits and Correct Rejections
measure.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #14. Standard deviations of reaction times (RT) assess intraindividual variability in RT referring to the two conditions creating hits and correct rejections as mentioned in Outcome Measure #14.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for Treatment differences in Standard Deviation of Reaction Time over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Standard Deviation correct rejections Load 1 over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Standard Deviation correct rejections Load 2 over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Standard Deviation hits Load 1 over time.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Pursuit Motor Control Task - Accuracy
outcome.description: A complex visuo-motor flexibility task that aims at measuring eye-hand co-ordination and fine motor control. By moving mouse cursor, the child is required to follow as closely as possible a target that randomly moves across the PC-screen. Accuracy is the mean distance between the mouse cursor and the moving target.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Pursuit Motor Control Task - Accuracy
measure.description: A complex visuo-motor flexibility task that aims at measuring eye-hand co-ordination and fine motor control. By moving mouse cursor, the child is required to follow as closely as possible a target that randomly moves across the PC-screen. Accuracy is the mean distance between the mouse cursor and the moving target.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for Treatment difference in Accuracy over time.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Pursuit Motor Control Task - Stability of Movement
outcome.description: A complex visuo-motor flexibility task that measures eye-hand co-ordination and fine motor control. By moving mouse cursor, the child is required to follow as closely as possible a target that randomly moves across the PC-screen. Stability is within subject variability of mean distance between cursor and target.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Pursuit Motor Control Task - Stability of Movement
measure.description: A complex visuo-motor flexibility task that measures eye-hand co-ordination and fine motor control. By moving mouse cursor, the child is required to follow as closely as possible a target that randomly moves across the PC-screen. Stability is within subject variability of mean distance between cursor and target.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for Treatment difference in Stability of Movement over time.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Go/No-Go Response Inhibition Task - Error Rates
outcome.description: Measures inhibition of pre-potent responses. 24 Go signals (open squares) are presented, randomly mixed with 24 No-Go signals (closed squares). Subjects are required to press a key if a Go signal (target) appears on the screen but to withhold a response if they see a No-Go signal. Error rate is the percentage of key presses to No-Go signals/total number of trials X 100.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Go/No-Go Response Inhibition Task - Error Rates
measure.description: Measures inhibition of pre-potent responses. 24 Go signals (open squares) are presented, randomly mixed with 24 No-Go signals (closed squares). Subjects are required to press a key if a Go signal (target) appears on the screen but to withhold a response if they see a No-Go signal. Error rate is the percentage of key presses to No-Go signals/total number of trials X 100.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and a non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for Treatment difference in Error Rate over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Error Rate irrelevant targets over time.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Flanker Interference Task - Error Rates
outcome.description: Measures ability to neglect stimuli interfering with predefined stimulus-response coupling. Child presented with displays of 9 colored squares. Child responds to color of central square by pressing left mouse key when blue, and right mouse key when yellow. Part 1 (40 trials), surrounding squares may be same color (compatible) or different (neutral). Part 2 (80 trials), in 50% of trials, surrounding squares have color corresponding to predefined key press for other hand (incompatible). Error rates are percentages of errors in response to compatible and incompatible signals, respectively.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and one non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Flanker Interference Task - Error Rates
measure.description: Measures ability to neglect stimuli interfering with predefined stimulus-response coupling. Child presented with displays of 9 colored squares. Child responds to color of central square by pressing left mouse key when blue, and right mouse key when yellow. Part 1 (40 trials), surrounding squares may be same color (compatible) or different (neutral). Part 2 (80 trials), in 50% of trials, surrounding squares have color corresponding to predefined key press for other hand (incompatible). Error rates are percentages of errors in response to compatible and incompatible signals, respectively.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and one non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for Treatment differences in Error Rates over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Error Rates compatible signals over time.

outcome.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Flanker Interference Task - Reaction Times
outcome.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #19. Mean reaction times (RTs) are computed for correct responses to compatible and incompatible flankers, respectively.
outcome.population: Number of participants with baseline and non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

group.title: Atomoxetine
group.description: atomoxetine: 0.5 mg/kg/day daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 1 week, atomoxetine 0.8mg/kg/day QD, PO for 1 week, 1.2mg/kg/day QD, PO for 6 weeks then atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO for up to 20 weeks.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: placebo: daily (QD), by mouth (PO) for 8 weeks. Then patients can take atomoxetine 0.5-1.2 mg/kg/day QD, PO up to 20 weeks.

measure.title: Amsterdam Neuropsychological Tasks (ANT): Flanker Interference Task - Reaction Times
measure.description: Task is the same as described in Outcome Measure #19. Mean reaction times (RTs) are computed for correct responses to compatible and incompatible flankers, respectively.
measure.population: Number of participants with baseline and non-missing postbaseline value at visit.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for Treatment differences in Reaction Time over time.
P-value for Treatment*Condition Mean Reaction Time correct rejections Load 2 over time.

outcome.title: Cytochrome P450 2D6 Genotype
outcome.description: Genotype characterization was used to determine participants' metabolic status.
outcome.population: All randomized participants.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
